Thats not the right way to think about it, youre sort of putting the cart before the horse. What determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market. eg if I were the only person who knew that the true odds of a coin flip were 5050, I would buy up all the bets undervalued 49 and under until all that were left were 5050 bets. So yes, by the end of that process it is the aggregate of wealth that determines the prices, what determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market before it. A market that rewards accuracy tends to be very accurate, even if 99 of the bettors in the market are clueless

Yes theyre called suckers and they lose all their money to sensible bettors and create an incentive for them to join the market in the first place. More suckers in a market will actually make it more efficient as the incentive to be accurate is now larger. Likewise, more attempts at manipulation Ive seen a lot of absolute nonsense going around at the moment that people are eating up actually incentivises the accuracy further. It might seem counterintuitive but its how it works

If you know for a fact its loaded its then not a gamble to say its loaded. You dont have to be a gambler you just have to have an incentive to make money. Or let the information get in the hands of someone who does. If someone knows, the market usually knows. Yes there might be rare cases where the one person who knows all 11 secret herbs and spices doesnt tell anyone else and doesnt like making loads of money for themselves, but as that information is not out there in any tangible form its stuck in someones head who doesnt join the market, no other predictive model could also know that information and betting markets would still be the most accurate predictive system out there. We can only compare them to other current predictive models polling etc and in that sense they win resoundingly and the evidence is there to back that up, even if you dont fully understand the mechanism behind it.

replies.text: I used to lament every bad event. Selling too lowearly, buying too earlyhigh. I changed that by doing 3 purchases of the same stock in a 10 day period. This averages the buyin cost, and made me stop looking for absolute bottom, and I either set a sell price and lock it in with an indefinite date range, or I set an alert 6 mos, 1 year, 3 years etc and decide then. The MOST CRITICAL part of the equation is to buy quality companies and to not chase meme stocks or trends. My buyholds are typically 10 years, and 75 of my holdings are divided paying stocks in companies that have paid out a dividend for X years.

how did you overcome it if you did? Experience helps. Knowing that even though a stock left the station without you, based on historical evidence you know it will very likely come back down again at some point. Also if it helps I also sell some puts.

There are many psychological pitfalls. One of mine is always remembering the wins but suppressing the losses. Eventually I just gave up and faced reality youll never beat the index anyway, so control the only thing that you can fees, and invest in low fee index funds based on your risk tolerance 7525 for me. Now that Im wise which really means not wise at all but older, my portfolio has grown and I also inherited, so now I have another puzzle that is above my intelligence tax strategy, because Im navigating inherited IRA distributions and small trust income. And also, how to invest the 25 conservative part in something that doesnt suck as much as bond funds. So, I use financial advisors and they do invest in individual stocks, along with broadbased long term index funds, to take advantage of tax harvesting and other tax strategies. I hate the advisory fees, but its needed once you have actual capital. Before that, as an individual, consistently socking small amounts into VOO, or VTSAX, and other index funds was not as exciting as stocks, but over time, was a helluva lot more profitable. Less stressful too. Generally, if you are betting on individual companies yourself, you may as well just go to Vegas. At least youll get free cocktails and access to the 12 leather steak and rubber lobster.

Most peoples criticisms in here are just as applicable to bad long term investing as day trading. But the difference is this. At any given moment there is a slightly higher chance that stocks go up instead of down. So you have rightfully recognized that you more often than not can buy a stock, watch it go up a little and then sell it for a small profit. But what you failed to recognize is that the time between selling your stocks and buying new stocks, the market is also more likely to go up than down. So you would want to minimize the amount of time your money is not in the market, and the best way to do that is to just hold stocks longer. So you can fuck up day trading and long term investing but its a harder battle day trading. Not to mention any tax implications or psychological issues it can cause.

replies.text: So, youve posted about this company several times. Im very wary of companies who are like, we use AI for insert use case here!. As an individual in an AIadjacent field, Im too aware that when you have a really great hammer, everything starts to look like a nail. I also very much doubt their ability to consistently match a foundation via internet. A, as a lady with a hardtomatch face and hideously sensitive skin, that has taken hundreds of dollars and years of trial and error with actual samples. B, as a former academic in a particular field, Im aware that even in person, quantifying the color of someones skin to an accuracy that could be used for research takes some specialized equipment, and even then youre leaving a considerable amount of variability out of your data. C, this is Il Makiages top review on reddit where I get all my skincare and makeup advice, such as it is Its not great. There are a number of complaints about the subscription service and pricing which raises questions about the repeat customers cited in the comment above. It seems like their advantage is primarily is in heavy, welltargeted marketing and advertisting, which honestly, ok, it might make them money, and I could be totally wrong. But its not a company Im going to be investing in personally.

I missed the elf train, even though I was an elf customer before their stock took off because they had cheap products of relatively good quality conveniently located in my grocery store. I didnt want to miss an elf opportunity again, because as someone that prefers online shopping, I should be the target demographic. When they say they use AI to get your foundation shade, I was hoping that they would use my camera to calculate pigmentation or something. But nope. It was just an online quiz that relies on you, the consumer thats not good at this stuff, to keep guessing which picture looks most like your skin. This has so many areas for problems unless everyone has the perfect screen settings for their desktopmobile devices. And when I finished the quiz, it wouldnt show me the results unless I put in my email address. This has always been a company pet peeve of mine. Especially when the results would be the products you want me to buy. So I wasnt impressed as potential customer, which is why I passed on investing.

The company has been able to build AI technology using data from over 40 million users to match products to consumers with 90 accuracy, compared to 80 instore. This has generated over 4 million customers, with more than half being repeat customers. Some concerns were raised about the companys ability to accurately match foundation shades online, but overall, the financial performance and growth potential seem promising. While the company is still relatively unknown, its worth keeping an eye on as it continues to disrupt the beauty industry with its innovative AIpowered approach. The stock seems attractively valued at current levels.

Smithson IT wrote this in their Q423 letter about the Oddity It is from a few months ago, but the share price is still around the same level. Oddity is another atypical investment for us but one which we believe has substantial opportunity for growth. It is the first ever IPO we have taken part in, and we did not do so lightly. We got to know the management several months before the IPO as we were approached directly by the company after they had been made aware that the business exhibited much of what we look for in a high quality, growing company. We were extremely impressed by the track record as well as the potential opportunity for the company. Oddity is a beauty and wellness company which creates its own brands and products to sell direct to consumers online. So far, the company has launched two brands, Il Makiage and SpoiledChild, both of which have been the fastest growing online brands in history, and now sell more online than large established beauty brands such as MAC. Traditionally there has been a large knowledge gap between consumers and beauty experts, requiring consumers to interact with a trained salesperson to match the myriad of beauty products to their needs and show them how to apply them at home. The large established cosmetics companies havent so far made strong attempts to sell products to new customers online refill purchases are obviously easier but Oddity has been able to build AI technology using data from their users 1bn datapoints from 40m users to learn how to match the right products to consumers with inputs including online questionnaires and, increasingly, selfie photos. Their 90 skin match accuracy compared to 80 instore equivalent has generated over 4m customers, with more than half of revenue now coming from repeat customers. This is not only a strong indication of the value of their service but is also much more profitable. We expect to see very high annual revenue growth for the next few years as the companys technology is several years ahead of established competitors and addresses such an enormous potential market.

Going to redirect to ChatGPT because it will answer the question in far more detail than I ever could The behavior youre describing aligns with what some people refer to as swing trading, which involves holding a stock for a short period days to weeks to capitalize on expected price movements. Its different from day trading, where traders buy and sell stocks within the same day, often executing multiple trades in a single day. Many retail investors might buy and hold stocks for short or long periods based on their strategy, market outlook, or financial goals. When you see people talking about buying, holding, or selling specific stocks, they could be Day Traders Buying and selling stocks within the same trading day to profit from small price fluctuations. Swing Traders Holding stocks for a few days to weeks, aiming to profit from shortterm market movements. LongTerm Investors Buying and holding stocks for months or years, focusing on the companys growth or dividends rather than shortterm price changes. Your plan to buy a stock and sell it after a couple of weeks fits more with swing trading. Many people engage in this type of trading to get a taste of the market or to try and make shortterm profits. If you proceed, keep in mind the following Transaction Costs Ensure the potential profit is more than the trading fees, if applicable. Tax Implications In a taxable brokerage account, selling a stock within a year could subject you to shortterm capital gains tax, which is typically higher than longterm capital gains tax. Market Risk Stock prices can be unpredictable in the short term, and your expected profit might not materialize. If this approach appeals to you, youre not alonemany people test the waters of the stock market this way.

replies.text: I searched for one a few months ago. I have in the past used a special situations newsletter service I cant recall the service but that service shutdown about 1015 years ago. What I ended up doing is to create a search criteria with EDGAR and manually look through filings. But it was too tedious so I abandoned the idea. If you are looking for a service these services are usually called special situation services. They provide news on potential arbitrage opportunities due to mergers, acquisitions, buybacks, etc.

Ive heard the term but never took the time to understand what it meant. Very cool, it sounds like this is something that should be accessible for retail and no reason for other odd lotters to keep it a secret, correct? Any odd lot Reddit subs?
Thank you! Ill take a look and report back if I find anything useful.

Odd lot arbitrage actually only really works for retail traders because it only works for small positions. Ie. less than 100 shares. Ive never seen a subreddit that discusses it. Probably because they dont occur very often at least for US stocks. I have seen them for Canadian stocks and Ive played around with 2 or 3. But the way that the taxes work because I am US based doesnt make it particularly efficient. Also there is timing so any arbitrage needs to take into account the current riskfree rate. So whenever Ive tried it at least for me the odd lot arbitrage was basically just capturing the riskfree rate but with a lot of extra steps. Thats the other reason why I stopped bothering with them.

Just to add to greytocs response and a bit more of an explanation of what they are. So generally when a company wants to buy back some of its shares it needs to incentivise shareholders to actually sell them, this would be done by offering to buy back the shares at a premium to where they are currently trading. Lets just pick the numbers shares are trading at 10 and the company offer to buy back shares for 11, a 10 premium. This is a great deal, you want to tender these. So you would want to buy shares to tender them at 11. What normally happens though is that the company will offer to buy back say 10 of their shares outstanding and that is all. What happens if 100 of shareholders try to take the offer to tender their shares? Well they get what is called prorated, where the company looks, sees that 100 of people wanted to tender and says, well we only have 10 to buy so we will buy 110 of everyones tenders. So if you wanted to tender 1,000 shares, they actually only buy 100 back off you. So what happens in practice is that they announce the tender and rather than stock shooting up to 11 a share it actually only jumps to about 10.10 as that is what you can actually get as an average fill on selling it back. these numbers are a large simplification for illustrative purposes to understand the basics, there are a few more things to consider. The oddlot tender provision basically just says anyone who tenders under 100 shares, we will give you priority and buy ALL of you shares first. So you are pretty much guaranteed to receive that 11 amount. Which is nice, as stock is still trading lower because arbitrage pricing wont force it higher as individuals can only buy up to 99 shares. So thats the basics. Its pretty nice when they come around. They are pretty limited in scale as obviously can only work for up to 99 shares in the company so you kindve need a high priced stock and a nice premium offered to make it a significant windfall. They can be nice to collect some free pocket money though if you get in the habit of just doing them with minimal operational overhead. Interest rates and time to return your money is obviously a consideration as greytoc said. Taxes obviously diminish your gains but dont they always and if its a pure arb itd be rude not to. Of course tenders can be withdrawn, updated, collapse etc. so thats a risk but one that tends to be okay to bear. A further complication is that in some of the best ones they are not actually offering to buy back shares with cash but with shares in another company. You will then bear some risk in that equity. Hope this helps.
Thanks for the detail, that does make sense. That thought was lingering in the back of my head based on the little research I had done.

The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

The short answer is Spirit junk bonds are very risky Junk bonds are an umbrella term that covers a lot of different ratings, they are not all created equally. Its like asking if technology stocks are safe...it really depends on the company. Bond holders get paid before equity holders, but other creditors get paid first. There probably wont be anything left for bond holders after the other creditors are paid.

Corporate bonds are unsecured securities sounds ironic I know. In a chapter 11, secured creditors, employee wages and pensions, taxes, and claimrelated expenses get paid first. Then bond holders get paid, followed by equity holders. These bonds are risky, but less risky than shares. If stockholders get anything, bondholders will need to be paid in full first. If you are daring enough to hold SAVE shares, then your risk tolerance is high enough to hold SAVE bonds.

I buy junk bonds constantly. I can look at companies that have technically junk ratings and know that in the 69 month maturities I buy they arent going to stop paying on their debt. Ill take the extra 150200 bps
The reason why Spirit bonds are trading down is because the odds that spirit makes their bond holders whole is low

HYjunk bond spreads are derived from their probability of default POD and loss given default LGD, which is expressed as a percentage of notional. You can imagine that as the POD goes UP and the LGD goes UP, the price of the bond goes down, and the YTM goes UP. So the price that youre seeing is the market pricing a pretty material default possibility. Debtors are typically the first in line to get assets in bankruptcy, depending on the type of debt. Theyre not covered completely in Ch11. Otherwise the market wouldnt price these bonds that way.

The SAVE 1 26s are also convertible bonds, making them the most junior bond in the stack essentially, these bonds are last in line for debt holder recovery. priced at 20c on the dollar right now is market estimation for potential recovery this level of subordination. high yield bonds can be an excellent investment, and have the best sharpe ratio profile of any fixed income asset class this century but chasing busted converts isnt the best strategy.

You will see those returns only if everything is ok with the company. So very risky and this is the reason why they are priced like that

I remember being a young wise man once. Walking out of a hospital, 27 stitches holding a chunk of my face on. A stack of discharge instructions.. 1 page on caring for a knife wound, and some 30 something pages about alcoholism, DTs, in patient treatment, the dangers of trying to quit on my own, etc. Im just not going to take shots anymore! Duh.. it was so obvious. As long as I didnt take shots at the bars anymore, this kinda shit wouldnt happen. I didnt have a drinking problem, it was just the shots that were doing it. Duh. So from then on out, I would make sure all my whiskeys had some mixer in them. I loved a good whiskey ginger anyway. But I had it figured out this time, no shots, no hospital. Easy money. Choose YOLO. Choose a pump. Choose calls on tripleleveraged ETFs. Choose selling your car to buy more shares. Choose 10x margin. Choose a fing big monitor with five different broker apps running. Choose crypto, NFTs, and that one stock you heard about on Reddit at 3 a.m. Choose options with expiry dates so close youll feel your heart rate match the ticker. Choose weekly updates from the SEC. Choose Robinhood, because who needs a functional trading platform? Choose stonks only go up. Choose buying the dip. Choose bagholding all the way down. Choose the rollercoaster highs of green days and the soulcrushing lows of red weeks. Choose laser eyes on your profile pic and tendies for dinnerif youre lucky. Choose mental gymnastics to justify FOMOing into meme stocks. Choose shtposting your losses because deep down, you knew it was never going to end well. Choose seeing your life savings evaporate in real time and thinking, This is fine. Choose ignoring fundamentals because who the f cares about PE ratios anymore? Choose thinking youll time the market better than every hedge fund in existence. Choose your moms basement as your trading headquarters. Choose burning bridges with friends who advised you to diversify. Choose watching yourself become the meme, one margin call at a time. Choose asking rwallstreetbets if you should double down as your portfolio bleeds red. Choose pretending its not gambling. Choose rolling the dice on earnings, holding through volatility, and always YOLOing the next play. Choose losing everything and starting over, because thats how real degenerates roll. Choose your fate. Choose YOLO.

My man, first of all whatever you think you lost was clearly never yours to begin with. The number one rule for anyone that isnt a sucker is that you dont gamble with money you cant afford to lose. The number two rule is you dont invest in speculatives that is gambling, not investing you invest in things that mean something, that produce things that people need, that provide actual meaningful value, in things that bring jobs, that benefit others thats investing. Do yourself a favor. Stop gambling. Go to work for a while and generate a nest egg that way. Along the way, maybe youll work for a company that will give you stock as a portion of your compensation. Convert that to a stable and diverse portfolio of low risk, low return investments for a while and stop trying to strike it rich in a flash. Most people spend their lives to earn a nest egg, some of them do get rich, most dont, and it isnt because theyre foolish or stupid. The markets are not where ordinary people get rich, they are where people who are already rich stow their wealth, and these days, if you notice, they dont really lose money anymore. This is a machine built by them for them and they influence policy to keep it working for them not you. They win, you lose, and you losing is how they win. Get wise and stop playing their game. If you want to play their game, then get them to invest in YOU, not the other way around. Get your life back and forget about getting rich by getting lucky or trying to beat the House. Do this and youll be rich enough with a stable life and people around you to enjoy it with. Build something meaningful that matters to others a pile of personal cash aint it.

Rock bottom is a phrase used, nobodys ever asked that before Ty yes it is. Also Pete isnt a real person but its also a demonstration of how we all work through addiction differently and that EVERYONES addiction is valid it also makes it easier when a regular meeting has a new member with an addiction some would view as lesser. As someone 10 years clean from cocaine, soda as a kid was my gateway into uppers and I to this day have a Mountain Dew addiction but it helps me not use and Id rather this than coke. And yeah you dont NEED to hit rock bottom you just need to realize you cant live like this and be willing to and following through with making the changes to better your life. Most people Ive met people who wouldnt have grown had they not hit rock bottom which looks different than everybody. I think the 12 steps arent for everybody but theres alot of help going to a meeting the community and others stories have helped me alot I recommend you go to narcotics anonymous it and rehabs and other medical care will and should take your addiction seriously. Do not denigrate yourself just because someone elses struggle may be larger it doesnt demean your own or lower there importance. Do not use quotes around the word addiction referring to yourself with caffeine as it delegitimizes and demoralizes you instead of accepting it is an addiction which is the first step which is on display over here youre admitting you have a problem and that there being worse things you can be doing isnt a lesser addiction, the thing addicts have in common is being an addict not that they do bad or worse things or have a giant struggle. Your addiction is very real and you are valid I tried quitting drinking caffeine several times but honestly its what keeps me sober at the end of the day Ik its another addiction but on my body its been a lot easier. With caffeine addiction I recommend titrating down slowly with daily intake

The entire premise of Kelly is a positive expected value from alpha, i.e having an edge. People here dont have alpha so the entire premise is flawed. Betting against the house in small amounts means you lose the same amount just over a longer period of time. Selling lotto tickets is statistically profitable to market makers if the tail risk is simply so low that by the time you sold enough tickets even if doomsday happened you have so much capital it hardly matters. People who buy 1 tickets to win 100 when the odds of winning is less than 0.01 is why they go bust in the long run no matter how conservatively they bet. People who buy 1 tickets to win 100 when the odds of winning are 1.01 make money in the long run. But can retail investors quantify those odds? Thats the funny part. They dont

I think the bet sizing vs expected value is good because you can look back in history for said expected value. For example if I have 1,000 bucks I want to 10x, I can look at the history of SPY, or better yet SPX, contracts and see that 10baggers happen multiple times a week once the strike price reaches over a certain dollar amount. The probability of 10baggers increase on eco data days and mega cap earnings days. But are people on here looking to make predictable bets to grow their account or are they just looking for a onetime 500bagger by going allin?

It is interesting applying it to nvida. Lets say we use the adapted formula for partial loss, and the worst would be 50 loss during a recession, and lets say it is 13 chance, and 23 chance of making 1015, pretty generous. The Kelly fraction is negative, so heavily against it.
Yep, special place for regards.

Kelly spits out much higher positionsizes for higher probabilitylower expected value bets than higher expected valuelower probability bets. While that makes logical sense and has some tight math to back it up, Im pretty comfortable overindexing on expected value a bit to accept a lower batting average for some monster home runs, especially when buying enough contracts to space out multiple sell targets with positive expected values. The probability of 10baggers increase on eco data days and mega cap earnings days. Depends on your model and what you trade. I trade SPX exclusively, and in my case Fed announcements, mega cap earnings, etc. raise premiums way too high for it to generate a buy signal, I usually get them when things are relatively calm. But are people on here looking to make predictable bets to grow their account or are they just looking for a onetime 500bagger by going allin? The latter

If you assume the 15 for a win the expected value for that bet would be negative. If you think those parameters are accuraterealistic Kelly is correct to tell you not to bet here. EV 13 0.50 23 0.15 6.67

As someone that has long term invested in Costco and followed the company intimately as in not just a regarded Yolo invester I want to mention a couple things. First about your mention of a stock split. While there are a lot of speculations that this is on the horizon for Costco due to its current valuation getting close to 920share now and has been up 24 ytd there is no official announcement about this happening. Costco isnt a tech company, explosive growth is not what they are about. It is an incredible and well run company of course and is considered a compounding machine, so its basically a golden investment vehicle for a long term portfolio to build wealth. A stock split would be great to see and could drive more investment, but I dont think it would happen as quickly as you are thinking. Lots of these successful compounding machine style companies dont move quickly, generally a 1 2 rise or fall is all you see from them most days. Nothing at Costco or other great companies like Mastercard or Moodys or even Texas Roadhouse happen quickly. They make announcements for things months in advance, do their earnings calls and thats about it. They are boring to follow for someone looking to day trade simply because their stock isnt volatile. But in long term investing they are absolutely top tier. Boring is great! Tldr Costco doesnt and probably wont move as fast as you think, even if a stock split is announced Monday. Just two cents from a long term holder of Costco.

Assuming this play does work, here is my plan of action come Friday 927, the day after COST ER. We cant just speculate on the move we have to speculate on how well execute the trade if it does work, to ensure the most success and tendies. COST ER is 926, after market. So, if earnings crush, forward guidance crushes, and they announce a split? And after market? This could absolutely rip, if those 3 aforementioned events happen. Could gap up pretty big. So, that said, my plan I currently have 15 options, up from 7. Will add more if COST dips more. For now, lets take what I will do with my 15 options on Friday morning. 1 I immediately sell some and take profits. I have 15 of the options. First thing in the morning, I will sell 25 of the contracts. Whatever amount will pay for the trade and net me a little profit on top of the fact. At 2140 for 15 1040c, I would sell however many it took to make 3000. Pay for the trade, and a little over 800 profit. So, Ill have made 3537 profit on the trade, and still have 1013 of the contracts left! Free trade, and 35 profit. Youve already won at this point. 2 Nothing. I wait until next week and do nothing. 3 Monday, the markets will have had a full weekend to process Thursday and Friday. Likely keeps going higher. The question is, when rug pull? We dont know, so we scale out of the trade and play it safe. 4 Monday by EOD, I scale out. I sell however many to be happy with the gains, what i would be sad about losing in profit pretty much. Lets say youre up 10k the following Monday. Ask yourself, how much of that 10k is life changing for you? What would you be sad to see go to zero on Tuesday? Is it 1000 out of 10k? Is it 5000? Only you can decide. Maybe it is 1000 in gains instead of 10k, or even 100k instead. That isnt the point. The point is, lock in the gains you would be sad to lose. I will be selling half of my position sometime on Monday. Will vary. Up to markets and price action when I do it. Say I have 10 out of 15 contracts on Monday, after Friday step 1. I will sell 3 of them at open, lock in the gains. Then, I will watch the chart the rest of the day. I will look to sell 23 more by EOD. 5 From Tuesday until Friday, I do nothing. I let the remaining 45 contracts ride. Zero or super hero. Maybe they go up another 1000 in gain, maybe they dont. I wont care, because Ive already made money. A big take away is this when trading options if your capital can afford it This is why grabbing more than one contract is optimal, it removes the emotions of wins and losses. Like my trade above, by scaling out in the manner described above, you remove all the emotions related to gains and losses. Friday, you set yourself up by not only getting a free trade. But also 35 profit. No negative thoughts now, youre already happy. Havent lost gains, or even money. Youre not only ahead on the trade, but now youre on a free trade with contracts left with 1 weeks time after a major catalyst. Monday, you lock in some more gains. Now, not only are you on a free trade, but now youre up 200 instead of 35. Youre even more thrilled than Friday! Free trade and up 200? Sweet! Now here is the best part. You dont give a FUCK what happens to those other contracts. Now? You can take them to zero expiration date, aka 104 and not give a flying fuck what happens. The rest of the contracts go to zero? WHO CARES? You made 200 on the trade. Congrats! But what if they continue to rip? Now, youre up possibly 1000 or more on the trade. Dont make that extra 800 by 104? Who cares, you made 200. And you didnt risk that 200 to try to get 1000. The idea is to trade in a manner that completely eliminates any emotions, positive or negative greed or fear. 1st order of business is paying for the trade and locking in a little gains. 2nd order of business is to lock in even more of the gains when it goes up or down for puts in your favor. Now, free trade, and big gains youre already happy with. 3rd order of business, let the others ride. Now you can handle all of the risk of them going to zero, because the trade was free, and you made profit. Regards

They were very much lotto plays. I risked 3 of my capital on DLTR, and 10 on DG. I was extremely confident in the 1 store plays. I have the same gut feeling about this COST play that I did with the 1 store plays. But the 1 store plays had much more reasons for me to be confident. The speculation on the 1 was for a few reasons. 1 WMT is now better than 1 stores, and has online ordering and home delivery. I expected 1 stores to get crushed, not only because their business model isnt as good as it was years ago, their financial statements were declining every year since 2022, but WMT is absolutely crushing many businesses. Especially 1 stores. 2 1 stores were trading above very critical levels that had no been seen since 20162018, and tested them last year and bounced. The thesis was, if these major levels were cracked 100 for DG and 70 for DLTR then it would be a massive bloodbath to the downside. Especially since both were below the 55MA 55 day moving average institutions are in, below 55MA they are out. 3 The options were very cheap and the odds of them cracking those levels was pretty probable. Enough for me to grab 100 of the DG and DLTR puts. 3000 risk on both turned into 72k and 18k respectively. This COST play is much different because it is already trading near ATHs. COST can easily continue to go down, short term. Next levels for COST to test would be 872, 862, and 850. A bounce off of either levels, and a close above 900 before ER next week would be massively bullish IMO. Furthermore, they created a shit ton of strikes this morning. All the way up to 1260 for some reason. Interesting that they not only created new strikes already, but so many of them. Makes me wonder if MMs are preparing for a split. But ultimately, no one knows until ER next week. Im feeling good about it, enough to increase my position to 15 1040c instead of the 7 I started with. Todays dip is exactly what I wanted.

Thank you for taking the time to explain. If I may indulge you a little longer This 100 of funds means 100 of what you paid for the contract, right? Until the contract is due or expires? If the due date is here, can the loss be greater? As in, you are forced to exercise it? Pay the difference or even buy the shares at the price?
Mostly because of the high share price. You can sell calls that are out of the money and make a few hundred dollars with a low risk of getting your shares called.

Your loss cant be greater than the contract. It can just expire worthless. If I buy a contract for 1.00 calls 100, and the stock immediately drops hard and never bounces back before the expiry, I lose my 100. Thats it. Theyre only worth something if there is a possibility they can be exercised for a profit. The only way to lose more than the 100 is to spend more than the 100. Options are just coupons to buy 100 shares at the price on the coupon. If the price of an item in the store is cheaper to buy without a coupon, the coupon is worthless. Its only worth something if that item is more expensive to buy without the coupon you know what I mean? And just like a coupon, they have an expiry date tp be used.
Oh, that makes great sense. Thank you so much man.

They have a cartel with Samsung and SK Hynix. They control 97 of DRAM production, hence control the entire supply. They use it to jack up the prices, sell out a major supply of product, then suffer below breakeven prices for a year. Rince and repeat for 20 years since 2002 at least. They oversupplied in 2022, in 2023 prices dropped, then they started to climb up in Dec 2023. They reached max prices in June when stock price hit 145 and kept them slighly below for a few month. Now they ramp up the production to sell of at the current prices, good chance we will see a good revenue growth throughout 1H2025. Itll be a downhill from then on, for about a year.
Apparently, this goes way beyond. Revenues seem to be cyclic for this memory business. Applies to all major players in this space. Now almost all are one the upwards curve.

And certainly the entire Trump machine is helping that rightwing streamers, Don Junior, JD Vance, all favoring Rumble more than any other platform. Its all fine and natural in the world of tech startups, and Im sure that they will eventually be a massively successful platform. _Eventually._ But I wouldnt be betting on them until they turn their focus to revenue. Ive learned that sometimes the best of news and the worst of news barely moves the needle on super stocks. These are stocks that have either enjoyed a huge recent run up, or they are so old that theyve split so many times that the stock is too diluted to react to goodbad news. The latter is almost like driving an aircraft carrier. You can crank the wheel hard, but the sheer size makes it barely move unless enough inputs continued good or bad news stay in effect long enough to compound the newssteering input. In other words, NVDA wont have a super spike either way.

High IV means that the options is like a new toy that everyone wants to play with and there is a high premium attached to it. When earnings reporting is over, no one wants to play with the toy anymore, so IV will drop a lot IV crush hence the premium will drop a lot.

The price of an option includes a volitility component. Like how it has a time component. Since it is expected to move alot over earnings, the opitions are more expensive. But after the big move the volitility component is much less, so the option is cheaper. It is technically possible to buy a call before earnings, the stock goes up, and by the next day the call option is worth less than the day before purely because the implied volitiliy made it so expensive the day prior. Look up the greeks about options.

I dont know why people ignore trends. The economy is a mack truck, not a motorcycle. It doesnt turn on a dime. 5 unemployment is pretty much baked in at this point. Its going to happen at some point in the next 12 months...its not if but when. Even if the Fed cut the rates to 1 right now, wed still get there, because of the time lag of policy. The dire situation is that the Fed continues to pretend they can influence shortterm macroeconomics with decisions they make today. Like the single quarter or half point cut they deliver in September is going to do jackshit to arrest the clear trend of a rapidly declining work economy. Seriously, show my anywhere in this chart where the unemployment line starts turning up and then just smooths out or recovers without some kind of asymptotic spike. Once sentiment goes south, thats it. Fear is selfreinforcing. And were nearly there. Simply, we should have been at 45 Fed rate for the last few months, and should have been nearing a neutral rate of high 3s by the end of this year. Instead, were still severely restrictive. And at the rate the Fed wants to move, were not going to get to a neutral rate until mid2025, if not later. The dire situation will be recognized soon enough. Not everyone can see the iceberg yet. And as usual, when they do, its going to be far too late. Though on the positive side of things, I dont think itll be a particularly nasty or extended recession due to a number of positive factors, including most people being locked into low rate mortgages. Itll be shortterm economic malaise, the market will likely overfreak out, unemployment may peak around 67, and then well be back to a smooth sailing bull market. There should be some buying opportunities near the bottom though.

When I first started my trades, I went over all the derivatives such as options and futures, I used to be up a few hundred percent in 2 days of the weekend. But I couldnt control my greed, I blew my account, after that I took revenge trades, I blew my account 2 more times. I made a lot of mistakes during my trading days. Now, before I place a trade, I always look at the downsides first. My account started increasing bit by bit, my recommendation for you is do not gambling, dont trust anyone about their technique, especially Youtubers and coaches bla bla. You have to figure out your risk appetite, find your own way to make money that aligns with your own time, dont try to be an outlier such as WB or BNF. Getting rich gradually will stabilize as the mountain.

Well, RKLB is currently more of a satellite company than rocket company. Their main source of revenue as of now is their space systems segment. The investment thesis on RKLB is in their vision of becoming an endtoend space company with capabilities of producing and putting their own space infrastructure into space. The stock will probably skyrocket in late 2025 when their new rocket Neutron that will launch these constellations, is flying successfully. Approximately a year forward from there, when RKLB announces its constellation the stock will probably skyrocket again. As the TAM of the space industry is growing and the race for militaries and big tech companies to own a share of the constellations in space, to not fall behind, starts to accelerate, Ill be glad that i kept my shares for the long term. Personally my portfolio is widely concentrated in RKLB and Im following the company closely and have been doing so for the past two years. My rough estimation of when Ill start trimming the position is no earlier than 2030.

Short term earnings have been priced in. long term, growth will rely on the continued relevancy of AI. Either it needs to become extremely profitable or become essential to remaining competitive. Theres a huge level of fear that the capex will be for naught and it will be a fad. Not such a big deal for other tech that have diversified revenue streams but for NVIDIA it would be a death stroke until such point as AI developed to the point that it is commercially viable. Who knows how long that would be or if it would even be based on the same hardware. Also, tech represents the early adoption part of the bell curve which means it is the first to suffer pull backs in tough macro economic settings when people are more conservative, hence why essentials like utilities preform well and are popular in those times. A mix of the two is what is causing the latest pull back and due to NVDAs dominance, other semi conductor companies have seen mixed earnings. The latest earning coupled with the price correction should create a lot of confidence which is good for another rally.

Now is an ideal time, because the stock is already dumped so much, a lot of downside risk has already been accounted for. Plus the IV is just insane right now. Check this out Right now, you can sell a CSP on an 80 strike expiring on January 17. This is going to pay you a 9 premium, over 163 days, which is going to annualize to 20 a year. Nvidia would have to drop another 20 to ever hit that strike, and lets say it does, at that point youre basically buying it for a 50 discount from its alltime high. Even better, instead of a CSP, sell a deep ITM CC at the same strike. That way the contract value depreciates with the stock price, since its a bullish play. So if the stock actually approaches 80 and you want to get out of dodge, theres a very high likelihood you can rebuy your contract for a fraction of what you sold it for, heavily managing your risk.

Selling puts is very similar to selling insurance for a high premium to people worried about a stock going lower. In high implied volatility stocks, the premium is high. That is you, the insurance seller, gets paid for this. I personally think this stock selling is a combination of irrational fear of long Blackwell delay and economy fear. Further, the news about a so called design flaw is really go questionable validity or usefulness.. If a stock goes below the strike price the option seller will typically find they automatically bought the underlying stock at the lower price. One of course picks up a premium for selling this insurance policy. Its a great way to generate extra cashflow similarly to covered calls. One typically sells puts when they would mind owning the stock anyway but also wants guaranteed cashflow.

Those who sell options have the obligation to do whatever the buyer of the option wants to do. So if the seller sells on expiry, then OP will get assigned and has to buy those shares at that strike price
You should learn how options work before trading them

Hi Paul (& James),I agree ~30% shorts is likely holding the stock price back. However, I take a slightly different view to you both (But I'm not saying I'm right!).My view is the shorts holding back the stock price is an opportunity for odd to buy back judiciously as the price comes under pressure. I'm a tad disappointed that only $10m was bought up to earnings (out of the $140m available), particularly given CEO/OH asserted in his prepared remarks that the price offered 'incredible value', but I believe management (CEO and CFO) knows what it is doing and is likely keeping its powder dry as a hedge against the shorts. That said, after very good results a few days' ago, it would be good if they added ~$30m of the $140m at <$40.Do either of you know what the bear case for the shorts is?! 30% is huge, so shorts should have a compelling case beyond Israeli tech/consumer being stretched etc.

Nailed it. I wonder if deploying the remaining $140MM on the buy back will squeeze them out. I think itll be hard pressed to stay below $46 for long. Too much positive forward guidance. Time, time, time, just give it time.Currently sitting at a 25x P/E, historically been trading at a 30x P/E.30x P/E after Q2 is $46, 30x P/E based on forward guidance would be $52 range, which lines up nicely with analysts 1 year estimates.

I don't quite understand this drop today on what was undeniably a super quarterly performance by ODD. 
So HELE a few weeks back had recession-like earnings and stock got crushed. They saw consumer weakness most concentrated in their beauty division, which is mostly hair care. I saw this and wondered if a slow down might have occurred at ODD. 
After the  close today ELF is down 10% after reporting their performance. I have not reviewed their results as of yet. 
I'm convinced the huge short position in ODD is the problem. Stock is heavy w/ institutional and insider ownership. It lacks liquidity and the shorts know this. They have mngmt pinned knowing they can't sell and institutions see no reason to add. 
Co CFO is from Goldman,  who I believe banked the IPO. I've been investing long enough to know that Goldman will enable shorts. It is going to take several more quarters of good earnings to shed  these shorts. They are shorting 30% + of the float. Buy back news -upped guidance didn't help. I sold 3/4 my position w/great reluctance but also with measured prudence. I hope this Mngmt team knows how to deal with these shorts. They will eventually; more likely soon attack.
